item.title: Small Business Idea: AI Interview Synthesis Co-pilot
item.content:encoded:
AI Interview Synthesis Co-pilot: Your Cognitive Sidekick for User Research

Brief Description

This idea proposes a minimalist, AI-powered web tool designed to act as an "extended cognition" aid for qualitative researchers. Its core function is to rapidly process raw interview transcripts or notes, offloading the labor-intensive initial phase of identifying emergent themes and summaries. Instead of manual highlighting and note-taking across dozens of documents, the AI provides an instant, digestible summary, freeing up the researcher's mental capacity for deeper interpretation and strategic analysis.

Core Value Proposition

Qualitative research, while invaluable, is cognitively demanding and time-consuming, particularly in the synthesis phase. This tool dramatically reduces the time and mental fatigue associated with early-stage qualitative data analysis (e.g., identifying initial themes from interview notes). It allows researchers to move past the tedious data compilation into higher-level thinking, thereby accelerating insight generation and improving the overall efficiency and quality of user research efforts. It's not about replacing human insight but augmenting it.

Target Customers

  • UX Researchers: Individuals or small teams conducting user interviews, usability studies, and ethnographic research.
  • Product Managers/Designers: Those who occasionally conduct informal user interviews but lack specialized research tooling.
  • Academic Researchers: Students and faculty in social sciences, humanities, or design fields dealing with interview data.
  • Market Researchers: Professionals analyzing qualitative feedback from focus groups or in-depth interviews.
  • Indie Developers & Founders: Building their first products and talking to early customers, needing quick synthesis.

Minimum Viable Product (MVP) Scope (Implementable in a Day)

The goal is to demonstrate the core value with absolute minimal effort, allowing for immediate feedback and iteration.

  1. Simple Web Interface: A single web page with a large, plain text area.
  2. Input: Users paste raw, unformatted interview transcript text or bullet-point notes into the text area.
  3. Process Button: A clear button (e.g., "Analyze Notes," "Get Themes").
  4. AI Integration: On button click, the pasted text is sent directly to a publicly available LLM API (e.g., OpenAI's GPT-4o, Anthropic's Claude 3.5 Sonnet). The prompt should instruct the LLM to:
    • "Identify 3-5 core themes from the following user interview notes."
    • "For each theme, provide a one-sentence summary and extract 1-2 direct quotes or paraphrases from the notes that exemplify it."
  5. Output Display: The LLM's response is displayed directly below the input text area, as plain text, within the same page.
  6. No Persistency: No user accounts, no saving of inputs or outputs. It's a "fire-and-forget" utility.
  7. No Advanced Features: No file uploads, no multiple interviews, no editing, no sophisticated UI. Just the raw cognitive offload.

This "single-day" MVP proves the concept of AI as a cognitive assistant for qualitative synthesis. It delivers immediate, tangible value by taking a messy input and providing structured, initial themes, paving the way for further development like user accounts, project management, advanced analysis (sentiment, specific entities), and integration with other research tools.
